title: 109_s1739
content: SECTION 1. RELEASE OR DETENTION OF A MATERIAL WITNESS. Amendments to Title 18 include Section 3144, which pertains to the release or detention of a material witness in criminal cases before a court of the United States. A judicial officer may order the arrest of a person as a material witness if there is probable cause to believe their testimony is material in the case. A judicial officer may waive the summons or subpoena requirement if clear and convincing evidence shows that the service of a summons or subpoena is unnecessary. A judicial officer may waive the summons or subpoena requirement if clear and convincing evidence shows that the service is likely to result in the person fleeing or cannot secure their appearance. A warrant for a material witness must contain the name of the witness or a description if the name is unknown. A warrant for a material witness must contain the name or a description of the witness, specify the need for their testimony in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding, and command their prompt arrest and appearance before a judicial officer. A warrant for a material witness must contain the name or description of the witness, specify the need for their testimony in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding, command their prompt arrest, inform them of their right to counsel, and be signed by a judicial officer for execution. The warrant issued under subsection (a) must be signed by a judicial officer and executed by arresting the material witness. Upon arrest, the officer must show the warrant to the witness. Upon arrest of a material witness, the officer must possess and show the warrant. If the officer does not have the warrant at the time of arrest, they must inform the witness of its existence and purpose, and provide it upon request. After executing a warrant for a material witness, the officer must return the warrant to the judicial officer. If the warrant is unexecuted, it can be requested by the attorney for the United States Government. After executing a warrant for a material witness, the warrant must be returned to the judicial officer. An unexecuted warrant can be requested by the attorney for the United States Government and canceled by a judicial officer. A material witness arrested under the warrant must be brought promptly before a judicial officer for an initial appearance. Upon arrest, a material witness must be brought before a judicial officer without delay. The initial appearance can take place in the district of arrest or an adjacent district if it is more convenient or if the warrant was issued there. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant against them and the supporting documents. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant against them, the supporting documents, and their right to counsel. The witness should be allowed to consult with counsel and be released or detained as per subsection (d). At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant, allow them to consult with counsel, and decide on their release or detention as per subsection (d). If the witness cannot obtain counsel, they should be given a reasonable opportunity to do so. If the initial appearance is in a different district, the witness may be transferred there if the judicial officer confirms their identity. Upon appearance before a judicial officer, a material witness arrested under a warrant issued in a different district may be released or detained based on the officer's findings of the witness's identity. A material witness arrested under a warrant may be released by a judicial officer on personal recognizance or bond unless there is clear evidence they may not appear as required. "A material witness may be released on personal recognizance or bond unless there is clear evidence they may not appear as required. Testimony can be secured by deposition if the witness cannot comply with release conditions." After a hearing, if no conditions assure a witness's appearance, they may be detained for up to 5 days or until testimony is secured by deposition. If conditions do not assure a witness's appearance, a judicial officer may order their detention for up to 5 days or until their testimony is secured. The detention can be extended upon motion of a party. Upon motion of a party, detention under subparagraph (A) may be extended for up to 5 days or until the witness's testimony is secured. Detention under subparagraph (A) may be extended for up to 5 days or until the witness's testimony is secured, with a limit of 30 days in criminal cases and 10 days in other cases. The detention of a witness can be extended for up to 5 days or until their testimony is obtained, with a maximum of 30 days in criminal cases and 10 days in other cases. A motion for extension must show good cause for why the witness's testimony could not be obtained earlier through deposition or court appearance. The judicial officer, in deciding whether to release or detain a material witness, must consider the witness's history and characteristics. The witness must demonstrate good cause for why their testimony could not be obtained earlier through deposition or court appearance. The judicial officer, when deciding on the release or detention of a material witness, must consider the witness's history and characteristics. The release order must meet certain requirements, and a detention order must also comply with specific criteria. A detention order for a material witness must comply with specific requirements, including being held separately from individuals charged with or convicted of a crime and under the least restrictive conditions possible. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the use of detention orders for material witnesses by the United States Government. The report should include the number of warrants sought and granted under this section. The Attorney General must provide an annual reporty to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the use of detention orders for material witnesses by the United States Government. The report should include the number of warrants sought and granted under this section, as well as details on material witnesses arrested and the average number of days their testimony was not secured. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to the Judiciary Committees on the use of detention orders for material witnesses. The report should include the number of warrants sought and granted, details on material witnesses arrested, and the average number of days their testimony was not secured. Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to supervise the detention of defendants awaiting trial and persons held as material witnesses within the district to eliminate unnecessary detention.
